answer: During plain radiography, X-rays passing through different tissues are attenuated differently - air attenuates the least, fat more than air but less than water, and bone the most. These varying levels of attenuation cause corresponding variations in the exposure of the photographic film. After development, areas where fewer X-rays passed through appear lighter due to lower exposure (like bones appearing white because fewest X-rays reached those parts), whereas areas with higher exposures (due to fewer X-rays being blocked, like lung spaces filled with air) appear darker.

Step 2: Different materials within the body attenuate X-rays at various rates: air does so minimally, fat somewhat more than air, water even further, and bone maximally.  
Step 3: Given this variation in attenuation, when X-rays hit a photographic film placed behind the subject, areas with denser materials like bone block more X-rays, resulting in lesser exposure of the film in those spots compared to softer tissues or air-filled cavities.  
Step 4: Upon developing the film, areas receiving minimal exposure (because many X-rays were absorbed or scattered away, typically where dense objects lie) become visually distinguishable from areas subjected to greater amounts of X-ray penetration (where fewer X-rays were attenuated), thus illustrating structural differentiation between soft and hard tissues internally.
